dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: seeyeah... Everett and Pete exchange significant looks. Delmar, howe is less sensitive to the Babyface's mood.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: »+.I dunno... who cares... Delmar stares at Everett, who looks appraisingly at Georg retreating back. Pete scrambles to pick up the loose mone

Yep, it's like our friend George is a alley cat and his own damn humors're swingin’ him by the tail. But don't worry, Delmar he'll be back on top again. I don't think we've heard the last of George Nelson. Delmar, gazing out at the blackness that has closed over George Nelson, hasn't really been listening. He turns sa back.

dialogues.speaker: DELMAR

After looking blearily about for a moment, Delmar starts staggers to his feet.

dialogues.text: But...

dialogues.text: .+.With my added time for the escape, I don't get out now 'til 1987... I'll be eighty-four years old. Delmar, not angry himself, is trying to work it out.

dialogues.text: Boys, we was chained together. I hadda tell ya somethin’. Bustin’ out alone was not a option!

dialogues.speaker: PETE

dialogues.text: I'U only be eighty-two. Pete lunges at Everett.

dialogues.speaker: EVERETT

dialogues.text: Eighty-four years old! I'll be gummin' pab-you-lum! They have rolled through some brush and their bodies are halfway into a clearing. They abruptly stop. dialogues.text: Oh my God! It is indeed Tommy Johnson

dialogues.speaker: PETE

Over in the bushes Everett, Delmar and Pete are straighte up and adjusting their appropriated robes and hoods, havi disposed of the color guard

dialogues.speaker: TOMMY
dialogues.text: +e +Huh? Everett is oblivious to the big man approaching from behi

dialogues.text: Who made them the color guard? Everett, Pete, Tommy and Delmar, bearing the Confederate flag, are retreating across the neutral ground separating the mob of Klansmen from the burning cross. The mob pursu in full cry. When the intruders reach the foot of the cross, Delmar tu He javelins the flagpole up and out toward the pursuing c Homer Stokes is mortified.

dialogues.text: Damn! Can't let that flag touch the ground! The crowd gasps and watches, heads tilted back, in silenc The only sound is the fluttering flag. Homer Stokes' eyes rise, hesitate and start to fall as th flag reaches its zenith and starts to descend. We boom down with the hurtling flag toward a sea of uptur white hoods. Dead in the middle is bareheaded Dan Teague. His arms are tensed out at his sides like a waiting kick-  returner. He squints up with his one good eye, judging distance and trajectory. From somewhere we hear a loud BOINK, as of a wire popping The flag flutters. The crowd is silent. Big Dan sets and... WHAP! He snaps his hands up and together. He has caught the flagpole. The flag has not touched the ground. The crowd cheers. Big Dan looks around, beaming acknowledgement of the chee From somewhere, another BOINK. As Big Dan's look reaches front again, his smile fades. His eye tracks up — up- CREEEEEEK! The fiery cross is twisting and starting to fa At the foot of the cross Everett snaps its last guy wire with his pincers - BOINK - and the four men sprint off. WHOOOOSH - As the crowd scatters, the cross descends towa Big Dan, frozen, looking up. It crashes in a shower of sparks and embers that oblitera Big Dan Teague.

dialogues.text: I'm sayin' we har this man away.

dialogues.text: Assa good idea, Pappy.

dialogues.text: Helluva idea.

dialogues.text: Cain't beat ‘em, join en.

dialogues.text: Enticements a power, wealth, settera.

dialogues.text: No one says no to Pappy O'Daniel

dialogues.speaker: SPIVEY
dialogues.text: Powas p'suasion

dialogues.text: What's his name again?

dialogues.text: Campaign manager? Waldrip.

dialogues.text: Vernon Waldrip.

dialogues.speaker: ECKARD
dialogues.text: Vernon T. Waldrip

dialogues.speaker: PAPPY
dialogues.text: Hmm... His folks from out Tuscarora?

dialogues.speaker: SPIVEY
dialogues.text: Tuscarora? Might be. I b'lieve they is.

dialogues.speaker: ECKARD
dialogues.text: Not a doubt in my mind. Pappy is disgusted:

dialogues.speaker: PAPPY
dialogues.text: You don't know where his goddamn folks from; you speakin' outcha asshole.

dialogues.speaker: ECKARD
dialogues.text: Well now Pappy I wouldn't put it that strong... As the three men make their way up the steps, Eckard's vo is fading:

dialogues.speaker: ECKARD
dialogues.text: ..sbut p'haps yaw right... In wide shot, they disappear into the building A reverse shows the wide shot to have been the point-of-v of Everett, Pete, Delmar and Tommy, who peek out from the mouth of an alley. Everett hisses his intelligence

dialogues.speaker: EVERETT
dialogues.text: Well, it's a invitation-only affair; we'll have to sneak in through the service entrance—

dialogues.speaker: PETE
dialogues.text: Wait a minute — who elected you leader a this outfit? Since we been followin your lead we got nothin’ but trouble I gotten this close to bein' strung up, n'consumed in a fire, 'n whipped no end, 'n sunstroked, 'n soggied -

dialogues.speaker: DELMAR
dialogues.text: 'N turned into a frog -

dialogues.speaker: EVERETT
dialogues.text: He was never turned into a frog! Delmar sulks:

dialogues.speaker: DELMAR
dialogues.text: Almost loved up though. Everett is stunned.

dialogues.speaker: EVERETT
dialogues.text: So you're against me now, too!... Is that how it is, boys? Silence. No one wants to meet Everett's eye. He is sadden

dialogues.speaker: EVERETT
dialogues.text: The whole world and God Almighty... and now you. Well, maybe I deserve this. Boys, I... I know I've made some tactical mistakes. But if you'll just stick with me; I need your help And I've got a plan. Believe me, boys, we can fix this thing! I can get my wife back! We can get outta here! Headlights play; the men suck back into the alley as a ca passes by. The car tools up to the banquet hall and Homer Stokes eme with his midget. dialogues.speaker: STOKES
dialogues.text: ...goddamn disgrace. Made a travesty of the entire evenin'... They too start up the stairs. Stokes's pace is brisk and midget hops awkwardly to keep up.

dialogues.speaker: STOKES
dialogues.text: ...what I wouldn't give to get my hands on those agitators. Whoever heard a such behavior. Even among culluds. Or mulattos, maybe - I suspect some miscegenation in their heritage... how else you goin’ explain it — usin’ the Confed'it flag as a missile...

dialogues.text: Everett, Pete, Delmar and Tommy are entering through the back door. The blackface has been scrubbed off but all fo now wear long gray beards as disguise, clumsily affixed w spirit gum. Each is carrying a musical-instrument case. They elbow past the bustling kitchen help

dialogues.speaker: EVERETT
dialogues.text: Scuse me... scuse me... we're the next act.

dialogues.speaker: DELMAR
dialogues.text: Everett, my beard itches.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is crazy. No one's ever gonna believe we're a real band.

dialogues.speaker: EVERETT
dialogues.text: No, this is gonna work! I just gotta get close enough to talk to her. Takin' off with us is got a lot more future in it than marrying a guy named Waldrip. I'm goddamn bona fide. I've got the answers!

dialogues.speaker: HEAD TABLE
dialogues.text: Out in the banquet hall Penny and Waldrip sit side-by-sid at the head table, surrounded by the Wharvey gals. Penny Waldrip are facing the hall with their backs to the stage the four bearded band members - Everett, Pete, Delmar and Tommy - take their places. Pappy O'Daniel stands by Waldrip's chair with an arm drap over his shoulder, leaning in to murmur confidentially Waldrip sits stiffly erect as he listens, frowning at a s in space. Suddenly Waldrip erupts: WALDRIP. Well that's a improper suggestion! I can't switch sides in the middle of a campaign! Especially to work for a man who lacks moral fibre!

dialogues.speaker: PAPPY
dialogues.text: Moral fibre?! He waves his cane, outraged

dialogues.speaker: PAPPY
dialogues.text: You pasty-faced sonofabitch, I invented moral fibre! Up on the stage, the band has launched into a song

dialogues.speaker: PAPPY
dialogues.text: Pappy O'Daniel was displayin rectitude and high-mindedness when that pencil-neck you work for was still messin’ his drawers A hissed Voice:

dialogues.text: Psst! Penny! Hey! Up here! As the two men continue to exchange sharp words, penny tu her head to look steeply up over her shoulder. Everett is up onstage just behind her. As the rest of the band continues to play, he is parting his beard to hiss d at her:

dialogues.speaker: EVERETT
dialogues.text: Penny! It's me! Dismayed, she shakes her head and tries to unobtrusively wave him away. He is undeterred:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, Penny, listen! We're leavin' the state! Pusuin' opportunities in another venue! I got big plans! Not minstrelsy; this-here's just a dodge - I'm gonna be a dentist! I want you and the gals to come with me She shakes her head vigorously and looks down at her plat as Everett continues pleading to her back

dialogues.speaker: EVERETT
dialogues.text: They're my daughters, Penny! I'm the king a this goddamn castle! Stokes has ambled up to the head table

dialogues.text: What're you doin’ here, Pappy? I guess someone let on there was free liquor, heh-heh.

dialogues.speaker: PAPPY
dialogues.text: Yeah, you'll be laughin’ out the other side your face come November.

dialogues.text: Pappy O'Daniel be laughing’ then.

dialogues.text: Not out the other side his face, though.

dialogues.speaker: ECKARD
dialogues.text: Oh no, no, just the reg'la side - This byplay is interrupted by a roar from the crowd The band has launched into 'Man of Constant Sorrow’ precipitating the huge reaction. Everett, still trying to get Penny's attention, looks up, stunned at the ovation Cry from the crowd:

dialogues.speaker: VOICE

dialogues.speaker: PAPPY
dialogues.text: Holy-moly. These boys're a hit!

dialogues.speaker: JUNIOR
dialogues.text: But Pappy, they's inter-grated.

dialogues.speaker: PAPPY
dialogues.text: Well I guess folks don't mind they's integrated. Stokes is also staring at the band, frowning. He murmurs himself:

dialogues.text: Wait a minute... Everett catches Stokes' look. The two men look at each ot aghast. Stokes raises his voice accusingly:

dialogues.speaker: STOKES
dialogues.text: ...you's miscegenated! All you boys! Miscegenated!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Everett raises the volume of his singing. Stokes cries ou

dialogues.speaker: STOKES
dialogues.text: These boys is not white! These boys is not white! Hell, they ain't even ol'-timey! I happen to know, ladies'n gentlemen, this band a miscreants here, this very evening, they interfered with a lynch mob inna performance of its duties! The crowd stares at him, stone-faced. dialogues.text: It's true! I b'long to a certain society, I don't believe I gotta mention its name, heh-heh... Nobody joins in the laugh; Stokes slowly strangles on it.

dialogues.speaker: STOKES
dialogues.text: ...Ahem. And these boys here trampled all over our venerated observances an' rich'ls! Now this-here music is over! I aim to -

dialogues.speaker: STOKES
dialogues.text: And they convicts! Fugitives, folks, escaped off the farm! This cuts no ice; the boos have become overwhelming.

dialogues.text: Folks, these boys gotta be remanded the 'thorities! Criminals! And I happen to have it from the highest authority that that Neegra sold his soul to the devil! He is hit by a tomato. Stokes is being pelted by foodstuffs. Shielding himself w one arm, he bellows into the mike:

dialogues.speaker: STOKES
dialogues.text: Wait a minute! Wait a minute! Is you is or is you ain't my constichency?

dialogues.text: Is you is or is you ain't - A disgruntled audience member yanks out the microphone pl Stokes continues to mouth the inaudible words. Pappy is considering the crowd.

dialogues.text: That's fine, that's fine!... He drops one arm around Everett, the other around Delmar

dialogues.text: «+.Governor - that's one of our favorites! Pappy returns a considered appraisal:

dialogues.text: Honey, it's just - Shutup, Delmar - it's just -

dialogues.speaker: COOLEY
dialogues.text: End of the road, boys. It's had its twists and turns -

dialogues.speaker: EVERETT
dialogues.text: Waitaminute -

dialogues.speaker: COOLEY
dialogues.text: - but now it deposits you here. The goons are shoving them toward the tree. Three gravediggers, having just finished their work, emerge fro the three graves. They are shirtless black men with banda  round their necks.

dialogues.speaker: EVERETT
dialogues.text: Waitaminute -

dialogues.speaker: COOLEY
dialogues.text: You have eluded fate - and eluded me - for the last time. Tie their hands, boys.

dialogues.speaker: EVERETT
dialogues.text: You can't do this -

dialogues.speaker: COOLEY
dialogues.text: Didn't know you'd be bringin’ a friend. Well, he'll have to wait his turn -

dialogues.speaker: EVERETT
dialogues.text: Hang on there -

dialogues.speaker: COOLEY
dialogues.text: - and share one of your graves.

dialogues.speaker: EVERETT
dialogues.text: You can't do this - we just been pardoned! By the Governer himself

dialogues.speaker: DELMAR
dialogues.text: It went out over the radio!

dialogues.speaker: COOLEY
dialogues.text: Is that right? The leering goons, who have been lashing the men's wrists behind their backs, pause, their sadism stymied. They loo to Cooley for guidance. So too does the drooling hound. Silence. Finally:

dialogues.speaker: COOLEY
dialogues.text: +++Too bad we don't have a radio. The goons recover their leering grins and resume their ha task. The gravediggers stand next to the graves, leaning on the shovels. They begin to sing a slow and dirgelike ‘You've to Walk That Lonesome Valley’. Sweat glistens on them and trickles down their faces like tears.

dialogues.speaker: PETE
dialogues.text: God have Mercy!

dialogues.speaker: TOMMY
dialogues.text: It ain't fittin'!

dialogues.speaker: EVERETT
dialogues.text: It ain't the law!

dialogues.speaker: COOLEY
dialogues.text: The law. Well the law is a human institution.  Cooley gives the faintest smile.

dialogues.speaker: COOLEY
dialogues.text: Perhaps you should take a moment for your prayers.

dialogues.speaker: PETE
dialogues.text: Oh my God! Everett!

dialogues.speaker: DELMAR
dialogues.text: I'm sorry we got you into this, Tommy.

dialogues.speaker: PETE
dialogues.text: Good Lord, what do we do? Pete is in tears. Tommy is terrified. Delmar bows his hea to silently pray. Everett bows his head as well. He murmurs:

dialogues.speaker: EVERETT
dialogues.text: Oh Lord, please look down and recognize us poor sinners... please Lord... The singing of the gravediggers begins a mournful swell

dialogues.speaker: EVERETT
dialogues.text: ...I just want to see my daughters again. Oh Lord, I've been separated from my family for so long... The mournfully building song is now supported by a bass m palpable than audible — the song, it seems, rising out of the earth itself

dialogues.speaker: EVERETT
dialogues.text: +++I know I've been guilty of pride and sharp dealing. I'm sorry that I turned my back on you, Lord. Please forgive me, and help us, Lord, and I swear I'll mend my ways... For the sake of my family... For Tommy's sake, and Delmar's, and Pete's...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The rumble is building.

dialogues.speaker: EVERETT
dialogues.text: ...Let me see my daughters again. Please, Lord, help us... Please help use. The rumble erupts into a deafening roar A wall of water is crashing through the hollow. It engulfs everything and everybody. The cabin itself is ripped away; the Soggy Bottom Boys are knocked off their feet and all is noise and confusion

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A silent world. Everett tumbles in the current in natural slow motion. Suspended around him are scores of tins of Dapper Dan pom Other objects spin slowly by; framed sepia-tinted family portraits, tree limbs, a fishing pole, an outhouse door, frying pan, a noose, an old banjo, the wild-eyed frantica paddling bloodhound, a tire with a rope tied around it.

dialogues.speaker: FURTHER DOWNHILL
dialogues.text: The churning torrent opens into a lowland to become a new created river, fast-moving but no longer violent After a beat of hold on the rippling waters, the surface broken by the up-bob of a pine coffin The coffin floats downstream for a beat and then Everett pops out of the water next to it, gasping for air, shakin his head clear of water, and moving his shoulders to fini freeing himself from the rope round his wrists Pete and Delmar emerge nearby, gasping for air The men hang onto the coffin, which bears them downstream Dazed, they look around. The inundated valley shows only the occasional roof- or treetop poking out of the newly formed river. All is quie except for the gurgle of water.

dialogues.speaker: DELMAR
dialogues.text: A miracle! It was a miracle!

dialogues.speaker: EVERETT
dialogues.text: Aw, don't be ignorant, Delmar. I told you they was gonna flood this valley.

dialogues.speaker: DELMAR
dialogues.text: That ain't it!

dialogues.speaker: PETE
dialogues.text: We prayed to God and he pitied us!

dialogues.speaker: EVERETT
dialogues.text: It just never fails; once again you two hayseeds are showin’ how much you want for innalect. There's a perfectly scientific explanation for what just happened -

dialogues.speaker: PETE
dialogues.text: That ain't the tune you were singin’ back there at the gallows!

dialogues.speaker: EVERETT
dialogues.text: Well any human being will cast about in a moment of stress. No, the fact is, they're flooding this valley so they can hydro-electric up the whole durned state... Everett waxes smug:

dialogues.speaker: EVERETT
dialogues.text: Yessir, the South is gonna change. Everything's gonna be put on electricity and run on a payin’ basis Out with the old spiritual mumbo- jumbo, the superstitions and the backward ways. We're gonna see a brave new world where they run  everyone a wire and hook us all up to a grid. Yessir, a veritable age of reason - like the one they had in France - and not a moment too soon... His voice trails off as he notices something. A cottonhouse in the middle of the river is submerged to eaves. A cow has taken refuge on its roof. It stands star at Everett, who returns the stare. He shakes off the vision and clears his throat

dialogues.speaker: EVERETT
dialogues.text: Not a moment too soon. Say, there's Tommy ! Tommy has indeed just surfaced downstream, clinging to a half-submerged piece of furniture.

dialogues.speaker: EVERETT
dialogues.text: What you ridin' there, Tommy? The furniture beneath him begins to rotate in the current and, to keep his head above water, Tommy climbs in place like a hamster on a wheel. As the chest exposes its ribbe upper half:

dialogues.speaker: TOMMY
dialogues.text: Rolltop desk...

dialogues.speaker: STREET
dialogues.text: Everett and Penny walk arm in arm, the seven Wharvey gals behind. The girls sing ‘Angel Band' as the grown-ups talk

dialogues.speaker: EVERETT
dialogues.text: All's well that ends well, as the poet says.

dialogues.speaker: PENNY
dialogues.text: That's right, honey.

dialogues.speaker: EVERETT
dialogues.text: But I don't mind telling you, I'm awful pleased my adventuring days is at an end... He fumbles in his pocket

dialogues.speaker: EVERETT
dialogues.text: .+.Time for this old boy to enjoy some repose.

dialogues.speaker: PENNY
dialogues.text: That's good, honey.

dialogues.speaker: EVERETT
dialogues.text: And you were right about that ring. Any other weddin' band would not do But this-here was foreordained, honey; fate was a-smilin' on me, and ya have to have confidence — He is slipping it onto her hand.

dialogues.speaker: PENNY
dialogues.text: That's not my ring.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: — in the gods — Huh?

dialogues.speaker: PENNY
dialogues.text: That's not my ring.

dialogues.speaker: EVERETT
dialogues.text: Not your...

dialogues.speaker: PENNY
dialogues.text: That's one of Aunt Hurlene's.

dialogues.speaker: EVERETT
dialogues.text: You said it was in the rolltop desk!

dialogues.speaker: PENNY
dialogues.text: I said I thought it was in the rolltop desk.

dialogues.speaker: EVERETT
dialogues.text: You said -

dialogues.speaker: PENNY
dialogues.text: Or, it might a been under the mattress.

dialogues.speaker: EVERETT
dialogues.text: You -

dialogues.speaker: PENNY
dialogues.text: Or in my chiffonier. I don't know. Everett shakes his head.

dialogues.speaker: EVERETT
dialogues.text: Well, I'm sorry honey -

dialogues.speaker: PENNY
dialogues.text: Well, we need that ring.

dialogues.speaker: EVERETT
dialogues.text: Well now honey, that ring is at the bottom of a pretty durned big lake

dialogues.speaker: PENNY
dialogues.text: Uh-huh.

dialogues.speaker: EVERETT
dialogues.text: A 9,000-hectacre lake, honey

dialogues.speaker: PENNY
dialogues.text: I don't care if it's ninety thousand.

dialogues.speaker: EVERETT
dialogues.text: Yes, but honey -

dialogues.speaker: PENNY
dialogues.text: That wasn't my doing... Indignation quickens her pace. Everett keeps up, and the are pulling forward out of frame

dialogues.speaker: EVERETT
dialogues.text: Course not, honey, but... We are now on the Wharvey gals who follow in a ragged bun still singing. From somewhere distant, through the song,  can just hear a rhythmic clack of metal on metal. The second-to-last girl is the oldest; she holds a piece string along which we travel, still listening to Penny an Everett, off:

dialogues.speaker: PENNY
dialogues.text: I counted to three, honey

dialogues.speaker: EVERETT
dialogues.text: Well sure, honey, but... We reach the end of the piece of string; it is wrapped ar the waist of the toddler, who lingers in frame. She gazes down a quiet street at the edge of town that ends in an o field.

dialogues.speaker: EVERETT
dialogues.text: ...finding one little ring in the middle of all that water... His voice, and that of the singing girls, recedes

dialogues.speaker: EVERETT
dialogues.text: «+.that is one hell of a heroic task

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The string is given a tug and the little girl waddles out frame. A train track is thus revealed in the distance. The rhyth clack is from the hand-pumped flatcar. The blind seer pumps the car along the distant track, sin harmony under the Wharvey gals’ receding voices
